title: Starting with Github
content:
Introduction to GitHub

GitHub is a web-based platform for version control and collaboration on software development projects. It allows developers to host, manage, and share their code with others. With GitHub, you can work on projects with others in real-time, track changes, and maintain a record of all modifications.

 

 

What's Difference Between Git and Github ?

 

 

Basic GitHub Commands

 

 

Here are some essential GitHub commands to get you started:

1. git init: Initializes a new Git repository in your project directory.
2. git add <file>: Stages a file for the next commit.
3. git commit -m "<message>": Commits changes with a meaningful message.
4. git branch <branch-name>: Creates a new branch.
5. git checkout <branch-name>: Switches to a different branch.
6. git merge <branch-name>: Merges changes from another branch.
7. git remote add origin <repository-url>: Links your local repository to a GitHub repository.
8. git push -u origin <branch-name>: Pushes changes to GitHub and sets the upstream tracking information.

 

Download Github Cheat Sheet : https://education.github.com/git-cheat-sheet-education.pdf

 

Deployment through GitHub

 

 

GitHub offers various deployment options, including:

1. GitHub Pages: Host static websites directly from your repository.
2. GitHub Actions: Automate deployment workflows for your projects.

 

Getting Started with GitHub

Ready to start your GitHub journey? Click the link below to sign up and explore the official GitHub documentation:

https://github.com/

 

To Know More About Github Refer To this Video:

https://youtu.be/apGV9Kg7ics?si=QfCMffZY3X-kJStA
short: Unlock the Power of Github: Learn the basics and Boost Your Development Workflow
author: Kumar Piyush
